I Didn’t Think a Charleston Seafood Spot Could Surprise Me, Until I Went to Chubby Fish | Bon Appétit

Stay for the perfectly grilled b-liner snapper.By Hilary CadiganApril 2, 2019FacebookTwitterEmailPhoto by Mira AdwellFacebookTwitterEmailThis is Highly Recommend, a column dedicated to our very opinionated editors’ favorite things to eat, drink, and buy.Despite living in New York, I spend a lot of time in Charleston. It’s where my fiancé hails from, where my future in-laws live, and where I’ll be getting married in T-minus 25 days (no, not freaking out at all, thanks for asking). This means I spend a lot of time eating in Charleston and what that means is an endless array of trendy new seafood spots.Don’t get me wrong: They’re all good (it’s hard to mess up fresh-caught seafood when you’re surrounded by water) but they do tend to blend together. Which is why I was surprised by how much newcomer Chubby Fish surprised me.Chef James London’s dishes change often—a smoky and well-balanced mackerel curry, a grilled b-liner snapper doused in fresh ginger and scallions—but maintain a consistent degree of playfulness that could come off as hokey if it weren’t so well-executed. We’re talking crunchy-meaty chicken-fried cobia collar, caviar service with “bo rounds” (fried potato medallions in the style of beloved Southern fast-food institution Bojangles), and local sweets peddler Cynthia Wong’s “not fried chicken” (a drumstick-shaped chunk of waffle-flavored ice cream wrapped around a chocolate-covered Cadbury finger biscuit “bone” and dusted in crushed cornflakes ). Standbys like Nicaraguan beer and housemade plum mignonette for the perfectly-shucked oysters complete the experience: fun, unexpected, yet approachable enough not to scare off the aforementioned in-laws.Go there: Chubby FishExplore Bon AppétitHighly RecommendCharlestonSeafoodRestaurantsRecipes you want to make.
